constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: NEIPOL Name: MC1  Maldens and Coombe
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

description: Variation of Condition 1 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission19/01728/FUL (Demolition of Chalet bungalow and detached garage and erection of 3 no. terrace, two storey (over three floors) dwellinghouses, lay out parking spaces and gardens, widen vehicular access onto Gloucester Road and form new accesses onto Cleveland Road.  Lay out associated hard and soft landscaping,including new boundary walls and fences, and construct cycle stores and recycling bin shelters) to reduce garden sizes of plots B and C
decision_conditions: No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction method statement has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment. (j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.The demolition and construction of the development shall be carried out in accordance with the construction method statement so agreed.No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development or other operations shall take place except in complete accordance with the approved document titled Tree Survey Report dated October 2019 and received by the local planning authority on 14th October 2019 (hereinafter referred to as the Approved Scheme).No operations shall commence on site in connection with development hereby approved until the tree protection works required by the Approved Scheme are in place on site. No excavations for services, storage of materials or machinery, parking of vehicles, deposit or excavation of soil or rubble, lighting of fires or disposal of liquids shall take place within an area designated as being fenced off or otherwise protected in the Approved Scheme. The fencing or other works which are part of the Approved Scheme shall not be moved or removed, temporarily or otherwise, until all works including external works have been completed and all equipment, machinery and surplus materials removed from the site, unless the prior approval in writing of the local planning authority has first been sought and obtained.Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The vehicle parking space shown on the approved plans shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the first occupation of development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times. Reason: To ensure adequate on-site parking provision in the interests of highway safety, convenience and amenity, in accordance with CS7 (Managing Vehicle Use) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the walls of the dwelling houses hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of planning permission ref: 19/01728/FUL dated 28.02.2020.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with details and samples for all facing materials which shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning authority before any works above ground level are commenced. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples and completed prior to occupation. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using SUDs methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the development and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development. Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to building operations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays. Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hours during the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted, a landscaping scheme, including where applicable the retention of the existing trees, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only. Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted any  windows serving the ground floor WC and all of the first floor flank windows serving a bathroom as shown on the approved drawings shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the approved development, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all gates, boundary treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected.  The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before the building is occupied.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the  Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

The car parking shown upon the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard-bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and, thereafter, it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

The residential units hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has been built in accordance with the requirements of Category 2 of the Building Regulations document titled 'Approved Document M - Access to and use of buildings' Reason: In the interest of inclusive design and accessibility in accordance with Policy 3.8 of the London Plan.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential units hereby approved shall not be occupied until they have achieved as a minimum, a water efficiency standard of not more than 110 litres per person per day maximum water consumption (to include a fixed factor of water for outdoor use of 5 litres per person per day for in accordance with the optional requirement defined within Approved Document G of the Building Regulations).Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted  (2012).

The flat roofs to the rear of the dwellings hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted  (2012).Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling located on the corner plot of Woodlands Avenue and Branksome Way. The site falls within the Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character. Proposal Erection of a first floor side extension.The current application relates to the planning application ref. no 22/02561/HOU for erection of a first floor side extension refused due to the proposed, flat roof form. Consultations7 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Given the scale, siting and design of the proposed first floor extension, it is considered that it would appear as a subordinate and proportionate addition to the host dwelling and the surrounding area. As such there would be no unacceptable impact on the existing street scene as a result of the proposed development.Non-Designated Heritage AssetsParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.The application property falls within the Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character which is a non-designated heritage asset. As stated above Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in an adverse impact to the host property or the character and appearance of the surrounding area. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would  not result in harm to the significance of the the Berg Estate Local Area of Special CharacterNeighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: To protect amenities of the occupiers at No 43 Woodlands Avenue, the proposed window to the south elevation shall be obscure glazed and non openable below 1.7m when measured from the floor level, details of which would be secured via condition. As such, it is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a mid terrace dwelling located on Westbury Road.The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of a single storey rear extension, front porch extension (to provide wheelchair access) and conversion of garage into a habitable room (As details previously approved 19.03.2020 - 20/00138/HOU)Relevant planning history:20/00138/HOU Erection of a single storey rear extension, front porch extension (to provide wheelchair access) and conversion of garage into a habitable room granted on 19.03.2020.17/14259/HOU Erection of single storey rear extension, conversion of garage to living accommodation with associated elevational alterations granted on 18.05.2017. 17/14582/HOU Erection of single storey front porch granted on 03.08.2017. Consultations12 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Loss of Car Parking; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed conversion of the garage into habitable room and the front porch extension are considered to be acceptable and in-keeping with the host dwelling and immediate surrounding area. It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension (4m deep) would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth which are in this case up to 3.5m. However, considering the size of the plot and the existing extension at the neighbouring property the proposed extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of its scale, mass and bulk and the proposed design. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is noted that the proposed extension would fail the 45 degree test in terms of daylight/sunlight in relation to the patio doors at No 53A Westbury Road. However, given that the proposed extension would be located immediately to the north of this window, it is unlikely to have a materially harmful impact on the room it serves. Furthermore,  it is a material consideration that there is an extant permission on the site ref. no 20/00138/HOU for a similar proposal which could still be implemented. Therefore, officers consider that it would be unreasonable to resist the development on these grounds. Loss of Car ParkingOfficer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network. Officers note no parking restrictions on Westbury Road.  Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

ikThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.12 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would have a depth that is in excess of the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, however the proposed extension would have an appropriate roof form and modest height and as such would appear a subordinate addition to the host property.Officers note that the proposed first floor side extension and side and rear dormers would not strictly adhere to the guidance set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of roof form and set in from the eaves, however it is noted that these extensions have been approved via planning permission ref: 19/02178/HOU. As such, since there has been no change in the scale or design of these extensions, Officers consider this aspect of the proposal acceptable given that the previously approved application would be given material consideration in the assessment of this application. The proposed single storey front porch is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed extensions would have a greater depth closer to the shared boundary with 55 Nelson Road, however it is noted that this neighbouring property benefits from an existing ground floor extension, and given that a separation distance is maintained between the shared boundary it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of  55 Nelson Road by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light.Given the separation distance between the proposed development and 51 Nelson Road,  it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of 51 Nelson Road by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light.Officers note that openings are proposed in the side elevations at first and second floor level, therefore to mitigate against any loss of privacy for the occupants of neighbouring properties, a condition to ensure these openings are obscure glazed and non-opening below 1.7m above FFL will be imposed.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: While the proposed development would include an integral garage, officers note that the internal dimensions of the garage would not be wide enough to comply with the parameters set out in the Sustainable Transport SPD and therefore could not safely accommodate a car or constitute additional off-street car parking provision. Despite the fact that the proposed development would not result in any loss or gain of off-street parking on site, the existing on-site provision (1 space) on the hardstanding to the front of the garage would accord with London Plan standards.Officers note that whilst the proposed garage would not be appropriate for parking cars, it would be appropriate in accommodating on-site cycle parking in accordance with the standards set out in Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The applicant is informed that the submitted details are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 7 (Sustainability and Energy Conservation) of planning permission 22/00062/FUL, which states:Condition 7 (Sustainability and Energy Conservation) - Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy SI.2 and SI.5 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Relating to Condition 16 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 22/00597/FUL, the following details are required to discharge this condition:- Statement of competence- Details/plan of evacuation assembly point - Details of construction materials and relevant Building Regulations classification - Details of means of escape- Details of avacuation strategy - Details of access and equipment for fire fighting

Historic maps indicate that the 'Outside WC' and 'Coal Shed' form part of the  original footprint of the dwellinghouse/that the original dwellinghouse had a stepped rear elevation. In the absence of any evidence to the contrary and on the balance of probability it is considered that the proposed rear extension would therefore extend beyond a wall forming a side elevation of the original dwellinghouse, and have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse

Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans/documents submitted for the purposes of this application are consistent with the parent planning permission reference 20/02942/FUL, however, any inconsistencies would be resolved in favour of the parent permission. An Application for Approval of Details Reserved by Condition should not be used to evolve or modify the scheme in a way that is substantially different from that set out in the application.

Condition 54. A (Fire Strategy) of planning permission 20/02942/FUL states:Prior to the commencement of the relevant phase or plot (other than demolition, site clearance and ground works), a Fire Statement for the relevant phase or plot, in the form of an independent fire strategy produced by a third party suitably qualified assessor shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The statement should detail how the development proposal will function in terms of: 1. The building's construction: methods, products and materials used, including manufacturers' details;2. The means of escape for all building users: stair cores, escape for building users who are disabled or require level access, and the associated evacuation strategy approach;3. Features which reduce the risk to life: fire alarm systems, passive and active fire safety measures and associated management and maintenance plans;4. Access for fire service personnel and equipment: how this will be achieved in an evacuation situation, water supplies, provision and positioning of equipment, firefighting lifts, stairs and lobbies, any fire suppression and smoke ventilation systems proposed, and the ongoing maintenance and monitoring of these;5. How provision will be made within the site to enable fire appliances to gain access to buildings; and6. Ensuring that any potential future modifications to the building will take into account and not compromise the base build fire safety/ protection measures. The development shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Fire Statement and retained as such for the lifetime of the development. Reason: In order to achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure the safety of all building users. 54.B states: Prior to commencement for each building details shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority demonstrating that a minimum of at least one lift per core (or more subject to capacity assessments) will be a suitably sized fire evacuation lift suitable to be used to evacuate people who require level access from the building. The development shall be carried out in accordance with these details and maintained as such in perpetuity. Reason: In the interests of fire safety.Officer response: It is noted that the Health and Safety Executive consultee is satisfied with the submitted information to the extent that it affects land use planning. As such, the conditions 54.A  (Fire Strategy) and 54.B (evacuation lift) in relation to Plot B Phase 1 is hereby approved.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ProposalProposed creation of new basement level with front and side lightwells and front boundary alterations.Planning History22/01888/HOU - Construction of a basement extension with formation of 1 x front and 1 x side lightwells. Refused planning permission, dated 8 August 2022 for the following reason:(1)	The applicant in the absence of submitting a Basement Impact Assessment has failed to demonstrate that the proposed basement would not result in harm to land stability and/or groundwater flow and, as such, the proposal would not accord with National Planning Practice Guidance and policies DM4 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.ConsultationNo response received to neighbour notification/site and press notice.Kingston Town CAAC: No comments received.Historic England GLASS: No further conditions or investigations necessary. AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The impact upon character and appearance (including heritage assets); - The impact upon the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and- Basement developmentImpact upon Character and Appearance (including Heritage Assets)Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. At street level, the proposed development would be minimal in terms of its visual impact, with black steel grates with central clear glazing proposed flush to the ground within the front garden/driveway area. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts upon the character or appearance of the area or harm to the character and appearance of the Knights Park/Fairfield Conservation Area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Basement DevelopmentParagraph 170 of the NPPF 2021 states that planning decisions should contribute to and enhance the natural and local environment by preventing new and existing development from contributing to, being put at unacceptable risk from, or being adversely affected by land instability.Paragraph 178 of the NPPF 2021 goes on to say that planning decisions should ensure that a site is suitable for its proposed use, taking account of ground conditions and any risks arising from land instability. This includes risks arising from natural hazards or former activities such as mining, and any proposals for mitigation including land remediation (as well as potential impacts on the natural environment arising from that remediation).However, Paragraph 179 makes clear that where a site is affected by land stability issues, responsibility for securing a safe development rests with the developer and/or landowner.The applicant has submitted a basement construction and methodology statement, which specifically considers the impact of the proposed basement on groundwater, in support of the application. Officers are satisfied that the report is authored by a suitably qualified consultant.The borehole has encountered Made Ground (thickness 0.7m) overlying initially loose becoming medium dense to dense (very dense in places) sands and gravels, proven to a maximum depth of 6.0mbgl. Groundwater was encountered at 4.3m depth.The BIA does not identify any significant impacts from surface water or existing drainage. Similarly, the BIA does not identify any significant impacts from groundwater.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Accordingly, it is recommended that planning permission be granted.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.13 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - The impact of the development on highways and transportation; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed two storey side extension would be set down from the ridge of the original roof slope, and set back at first floor level, it is noted that it would not have an adequate separation distance between the shared boundary, and given that the proposal would also have a gable end, it is considered that this would add additional bulk to the proposed extension, which would significantly reduce the characteristic openness between the dwellings, and would ultimately detract from the prevailing pattern of development within the surrounding area.The proposed rear dormer roof extension on the existing hipped roof would result in an awkward and bulky roof form, given that it would not adequately be set in from the eaves or sides of the roof slope and down from the ridge, it would detract from the character of the original dwelling. Further, in combination with the proposed two storey side extension, officers consider that the proposed rear dormer with two storey side extension would combine to create an awkward and incongruous addition to the host property, which would detract from the established character of the immediate surrounding area. It is also noted that the proposed juliette balcony would be oversized for the scale of the proposed dormer, and given the height and prominence of the extension, it would visually detract from the appearance of the original dwelling. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: While the proposed extensions would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, given that the proposals would not extend further in depth, and neighbouring properties do not benefit from side facing windows, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would demolish the existing garage, however Officers note that the internal dimensions of the garage would not be wide enough to comply with the parameters set out in the Sustainable Transport SPD and therefore could not safely accommodate a car or constitute additional off-street car parking provision. London Plan policy T5 requires all development to include provision for cycle parking. While the proposal would include the loss of the existing garage, the provided plans show that a bin and bike store would be located to the front of the site, and officers consider this would be an appropriate location for dedicated cycle parking.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe application site is in Pine Gardens and comprises of a two-storey, a detached residential dwellinghouse. There is provision for off street parking on site and garden space the rear.The immediate surrounding area is predominantly residential in character. The site is not listed or locally listed and does not fall within a Conservation Area. Neither does it have any Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) on the site or in the immediate vicinity, or fall within a Flood Risk Zone. ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the conversion of the garage into habitable space, erection of single storey front/ side extension and alteration to fenestration.Consultation8no. properties were notified of the proposal. No representations received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; - The impact upon highways; and- Fire safetyCharacter and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Policy Guidance 38 (Front Extensions) of the SPD guidance is applicable to this application. Policy Guidance 38 of the Residential Design SPD advises n designing a front extension the following guidance will apply: Front extensions should be built at least 500mm from an existing bay window. New porches should reflect the character of the main house, appear as part of the original building and not be an obvious addition. Porches should be designed to be subordinate to the existing house and should not dominate the front elevation. The roof of the porch should match the design and pitch of the roof of the existing house. All front extensions should be designed to respect the symmetry of any existing front extensions or features of the adjoining properties. Front extensions that extend across the entire frontage are unlikely to be supported. Front extensions should not affect the existing parking provision of the development and any parking lost as a result of the extension should be replaced on site.The extensions would facilitate the proposed conversion of the garage as shown on the submitted plans as being given over to habitable accommodation in the form of an extension to a utility room, a pantry and a cloak room.It is considered that the proposed development would preserve and maintain the character of the area and would not detract from the character and appearance of the host property, in accordance with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy April 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Overall and in terms of residential amenity the proposal is considered to comply with policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy, 2012 and the Council's Residential Design SPD, 2013.Highway SafetyPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The site is within PTAL 1B. London Plan Policy T6.1 seeks to ensure a maximum of 1.5 spaces per 3+ dwelling. The application involves the conversion of the attached garage space. The area of hardstanding/driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used for parking of a car, and so the subject site can still accomodate a space which woudl comply with the LP.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionThe  proposals are considered to relate well to the original dwelling, would be subordinate in scale and would not have an unacceptably adverse impact upon neighbouring residential amenity, thereby complying with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 and the Residential Design Guide, 2013.The scheme is therefore considered to be acceptable and in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that retrospective planning permission should be granted

Condition 58 (Hoarding Strategy) of planning permission 20/02942/FUL states:No development within a Development Plot or Phase, shall commence until a scheme for temporary fencing and/or enclosure of the site (a Hoarding Strategy) has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, and the temporary fencing and/or enclosure has been erected in accordance with the approved details. The temporary fencing and/or enclosure shall thereafter be retained for the duration of the demolition and building works in accordance with the approved details. No part of the temporary fencing and/or enclosure shall be used for the display of advertisement hoardings, unless consent is sought for the Local Planning Authority. The Developer shall explore options for a living wall hoarding.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory external appearance and to prevent harm to the street scene, public realm, and to address air quality mattersOfficer response: The submitted information is considered to be sufficient. As such, the condition 58 (Hoarding Strategy) in relation to Plot B, Phase 1 is hereby approved.

The site is occupied by a two storey terraced building, located on the eastern side of Mill Street.The property is located within the Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation Area and Flood Risk Area Zone 2. Planning permission is sought for Demolition of existing rear extension and erection of single-storey rear extension.10 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals. No representations have been received.Historic England: Consultation not considered necessary.Kingston Town Conservation Areas Advisory Committee: No objection.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the Conservation Area;- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character, Appearance and HeritageSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The application site is located within the Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: An early suburb of Kingston Town Centre comprising houses of various sizes and designs dating mainly from the 1820s to 1900 around Fairfield, a recreational open space since 1855. In 1850 this conservation area was farmland and open meadows until Victorian villas were built on Orchard Road in 1860. Officers note the Conservation Area is very mixed comprising many historic and visually pleasing buildings however there are also a number of other buildings in the immediate vicinity with no historic or visual merit. The site is located adjacent to the Knights Park campus for Kingston University. The existing extension is currently inadequate habitable accommodation and makes no provision for open space. The proposed development has been designed to be sympathetic to the host dwelling, and is modest in scale and design allowing some open space to the rear of the property. It would not be visible from the street. Officers therefore do not consider the proposal would result in harm to the Conservation Area.The proposed single storey rear extension would replace an existing extension that does not provide a satisfactory standard of habitable space. The extension would be 1.5m depth with a slate pitched roof, providing a new kitchen/dining space and create a new outdoor space which the existing extension prevents. Provision for bike storage has also been made at the rear in the absence of a front garden to accommodate otherwise.  The extension would be finished externally in brickwork to match the existing. No objection is proposed to the modest rooflight. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: The proposed development would increase the open space to the rear , is modest in scale and design, and has been designed to respect the character of the host dwelling and surrounding properties, opening up the open space to the rear and improving the overall outlook for the host and neighbouring properties. Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposed development would not undulyimpact the amenities of neighbouring properties.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: As set out above, the application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. A flood risk assessment has been submitted detailing flood protection measures in accordance with the standing advice to ensure the proposal will be safe in terms of flood risk and will not increase the risk of flood elsewhere. As such, the proposed development is considered not to conflict with Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, there is sufficient space for provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Annotated dimensions must be included on all Existing and Proposed floor plans, site plans, elevation drawings, and section/level plans to show the key dimensions of any existing structures to be demolished/retained and dimensions for the proposed works. This is in line with the Council's adopted local Validation Checklist. Please amend and re-submit where necessary.
